loans.use: to prepare land for maize and wheat planting

loans.name: Mai

texts.en: Mai is 48-years-old with 2 children who are in high school. She has a small grocery shop in the local market and also sells artificial  paper goods. This shop was opened 3 years ago and it creates  stable income  for her to manage family life. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,736,000 Vietnam dong to buy more new products for selling.

loans.use: to buy  more new products for selling.

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita is 49 years old, married and has six children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 
Cristita has a food vending business selling native delicacies in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 12,000 PHP through Kiva partner NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.
Cristita has been in this business for ten years. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Ritchel

texts.en:
Ritchel is a 33-year-old married woman with 2 children aged 8 and 6.  Her husband works as a farmer.

Ritchel is in the business of food vending. She cooks viands to sell to her community.  Ritchel also supports her husband in managing their rice farm. She also helps sell their harvest at the market.  Ritchel works hard to sustain her family.

Ritchel has requested this loan to purchase fertilizers and raw ingredients such as pork and chicken meat and spices.  This will help Ritchel's family with their businesses.  In the future, Ritchel hopes for her children to finish college and be successful.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and raw ingredients such as pork and chicken meat and spices

loans.name: Juan Fernando

texts.es:
Juan es una persona que a pesar de las adversidades que le ha presentado la vida, ha tenido las ganas de salir adelante que le permiten superar estas dificultades y continuar progresando junto con su familia. Juan se encuentra casado y es padre de 2 hijos de 3 y 12 años de edad, quienes son su motivación para trabajar fuertemente en su negocio. Juan actualmente tiene un empleo como auxiliar de equipajes en el aeropuerto de su municipio, pero el salario que le pagan no es suficiente para sostener los gastos de su hogar. Es por esto que Juan anteriormente tenía una venta de ropa la cual ofrecía a una gran cantidad de clientes, y gracias a la buena calidad de estos productos, Juan pudo tener muy buenos niveles de ventas. Debido a circunstancias ajenas a su voluntad, Juan se vio en la obligación de cerrar su negocio de venta de ropa y dedicarse a su empleo como auxiliar de equipaje. Con el ánimo de reiniciar su negocio de venta de ropa, Juan aspira a que un préstamo le brinde la oportunidad de acceder a la compra de ropa al por mayor para reiniciar su negocio de venta de ropa. 
Juan espera que con este negocio, alterno a su empleo, pueda generar mayores ingresos para su familia, de modo que pueda ofrecerles una mejor calidad de vida y una estabilidad económica. Juan espera poder conseguir esta mercancía sin que sus ingresos mensuales se vean afectados, y de esta manera seguir ofreciendo el sustento de su hogar. Juan sueña con tener un gran negocio, el cual pueda ofrecer empleo para las personas más necesitadas y desde el cual sus hijos puedan tener una estabilidad económica para progresar en un futuro.

loans.use: Compra de ropa al por mayor para reiniciar su negocio de venta de ropa.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 35 years old. He is married with 3 children aged 4 and 12 years. 2 of them go to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 8 years. While his wife is a business woman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of her children and to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Sara

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de cinq enfants, Sara est une femme âgée de 37 ans résidant à Baguida. Sara est une marchande de maïs et de charbon de bois qui achète ses marchandises deux fois par mois au marché et le revend sous un hangar à la devanture de son domicile. Sara sollicite ce prêt pour commander des sacs de maïs et de charbon de bois en vue de stocker une plus grande quantité de marchandises puis maximiser son profit afin d’aider son mari dans l’éducation de ses enfants et aux charges quotidiennes éprouvées par la famille.

loans.use: Acheter 02 sacs de maïs et 02 sacs de charbon de bois.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 36 years old, single with 4 children. Her children attend school, 1 in High School and 3 in primary school.Janet sells milk and she has been doing this business for last seven years. She also sells fodder, vegetables such as cabbages and kales to bring in extra income. The prevailing market conditions in terms of demand for milk, good prices has encouraged her to replace her cows by a better breed which will give her 18 litres per day instead of the previous 8 litres.

loans.use: Janet wants to buy a better breed dairy cow to increase milk supply.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet has participated in the TEACH lending programme of Kraban Support Foundation where she learned a systematic way of keeping records of her charcoal sales.  She had put this system in place and innovation makes customers buy from her very quickly. She wants a KIVA loan facility of $750 to expand her sales.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Mrs. F. has sold new clothes at one of the markets downtown for the past 7 years. She has a well established business and carries several brands of clothing for the whole family. "I'd like to open another store and need a loan of $1,200. I hope everything works out the way I want it to."

Translated from Spanish by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Fabián vende ropa nueva en uno de los mercados ubicados en el centro de la ciudad, lleva ya 7 años establecida y maneja varias líneas de ropa para toda la familia. "Quiero poner una sucursal y necesito un préstamo de $1,200.00 dlls espero que todo salga como me lo he planteado".

loans.use: To open a store at another location

texts.en: Mrs. L. is 57 years of age, as is her husband. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper middle of Vietnam. They have a trading shop for building materials. Her husband is very sick so Mrs. L. has to do all the work by herself. Her three children are already living on their own. Before joining TYM she borrowed money from local money lenders, who charged interest of at least 2% flat per month. She wants to invest more in her shop and buy ornaments to sell as well. Her profit iscurrently $300.00 per month.

loans.use: To buy more ornaments and building equipment for her shop

loans.name: Librada

texts.es:
Señora Librada is 53 years old. She is a single mother of 4 children. Two of her children live with her. The oldest one is married and has his own house. Her other daughter died of cancer about 2 years ago leaving her 4 children to Librada who is taking care of them.

You can say she has been through a very tough time, but she has been able to move forward and she has been able to take good care of her family. Librada currently sells used clothes and used shoes which she buys at Ciudad del Este, one of the biggest cities in the country which is located about 4 hours from where she lives.

She started with a small side business from home. Thanks to her good-nature, she has been able to multiply her clientele. She currently has two stores. Her main motivation is to provide a good education to her grandchildren which she promised to her daughter when she died.

Librada is requesting a loan to purchase T-shirts, shoes, dress shirts and pants for the summer during the fall time which are less expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Librada tiene 53 años, es madre soltera de cuatro hijos. Dos de sus hijos viven con ella, el mayor está casado y tiene su propia casa; su otra hija falleció de cáncer hace dos años dejando huérfanos a cuatro niños, los cuales viven Librada quien se encarga hoy día de la crianza de los mismos. Puede decirse de ella que ha pasado por muchas pruebas difíciles, pero aún así ha podido salir adelante y darle sustento a su familia. Librada se dedica hoy día a la venta de ropas y zapatos usados que los compra de Ciudad del Este, una de las ciudades más comerciales del país que se encuentra a cuatro horas de la ciudad donde ella reside. Empezó con un pequeño puesto en su casa, y gracias a su ingenio y amabilidad ha logrado multiplicar sus clientes, y actualmente ya cuenta con dos grandes salones de ventas. La mayor motivación de Librada es la de dar una buena educación a sus nietos, para así cumplir con la promesa que le hizo a su hija. Librada solicita el préstamo para comprar remeras, zapatos, camisas y pantalones para el verano que en esta temporada de invierno están de oferta y tienen mejor precio.

loans.use: To puchase all types of clothes

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Mariana, 38, owns a little cafeteria where she sells fried bananas, boiled or fried eggs, some other fried foods, coffee, milk, and juice in the morning. At midday, she prepares rice with peas, fried chicken, and greens.

Mariana started the cafeteria three years ago. The loan requested is to invest in the purchase of a larger amount of raw materials for the preparation of the food she sells. That way, Mariana will better satisfy her customers´ needs, increase her income, and help her husband improve living conditions for their three sons (12, 10, and 8 years old).

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like bananas, eggs and green vegetables to prepare for her business

loans.name: Fuente De Vida Group

texts.es:
The community “Fuente de Vida” or “Fountain of Life” is a consolidated communal bank. The woM. of this group have worked and lived together for almost five years. The group displays great confidence and happiness in working together. It is a dynamic community and it contains a mixture of interesting young and older woM..

Before beginning to work with Friendship Bridge, many of these woM. worked as homemakers or artisans. Like the majority of woM. in Santiago de Atitlan, these woM. work making beaded jewelry and traditional weaving and they are paid exclusively for hand-made work.

However, they have decided to change their future by starting a business venture with Friendship Bridge. Now they want to change their status from that of artisans who are only recompensed for handmade labor to businesswoM. who are recognized for their talent.

For this reason the group is excited to request a loan of approximately $200 US, paid in nine installments, in order to invest in their successful businesses. The majority of the woM. work in knitting and embroidery of traditional dresses. They also work in the purchase and sale of fresh vegetables and the raising of animals. The woM. are going to use their credit to buy bulls (in order to fatten and sell them), to buy fire wood in bulk in order to sell it in the outlying villages, to buy beads in order to make jewelry and to buy raw material for making traditional dresses and embroidery.

The dream of these woM., which they are already realizing, is to see their businesses grow in order to be able to expand their homes and in that way install electricity and water. They would also like to buy land in order to build homes for their children. Finally, the consensus was that the businesses grow in order to send their children to school so that the kids can get ahead. Doña María Elena A. said: “My dream is that my son study in the university and graduate as a lawyer in order to fight injustice in our towns.” Thanks to the loans that they would receive from Kiva, this dream could be achieved.

For health reasons, one of the group members was not able to be present in the photo.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La ComUnidad “Fuente de Vida” es un banco comunal ya consolidado. Las mujeres de este grupo han trabajado y convivido juntas por casi 5 años. Este grupo de mujeres refleja mucha confianza y alegría al actuar. Es un grupo dinámico y tiene una mezcla interesante de mujeres jóvenes y adultas.

Muchas de estas mujeres antes de empezar con Friendship Bridge trabajaban como ama de llaves dentro de sus casas o eran artesanas. Como la gran mayoría de mujeres en Santiago de Atitlan, estas mujeres trabajan haciendo joyería de mostacilla y tejidos típicos y les pagaban exclusivamente por la mano de obra.

Sin embargo, ellas decidieron cambiar su futuro al emprender una aventura empresarial con Friendship Bridge. Ahora ellas quieren cambiar su estatus de una artesana que solo es recompensada por su mano de obra, a una empresaria a la cual se le reconoce su talento.

Es por esa razón que este grupo se animó a pedir un préstamo de aproximadamente US$200, a nueve cuotas, para invertir en sus negocios exitosos. La mayoría de señoras trabajan en tejido y bordado de trajes típicos. También, trabajan en la compra y venta de verduras y la crianza de animales. Las señoras van a utilizar su crédito para comprar toros (para engordarlos y revenderlos), compra de leña al por mayor y revenderla en las aldeas alejadas, comprar mostacilla para producir joyas y para comprar materia prima para elaborar trajes típicos y bordados.

Los sueños de estas señoras, que ya lo están viviendo, es que su negocio mejore para poder ampliar su casita y de esa manera instalar luz y agua. También les gustaría comprar un terreno para poder construir una casa para sus hijos. Finalmente, el consenso fue que el negocio mejore para poder mandar sus hijos a la escuela para que puedan salir adelante. Doña Maria Elena A. dijo: “mi sueño es que mi hijo llegue a estudiar en la universidad y se gradúe como abogado para luchar contra las injusticias en nuestros pueblos.” Gracias al préstamo que vamos a recibir de Kiva ese sueño se va a poder lograr.

Por problemas de salud una de las compañeras no se pudo presentar en la foto.

loans.use: In order to buy and sell traditional clothing and fabrics.  For the purchase of raw material for the making of traditional dresses. To purchase raw material for making beaded jewelry.

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah M. is requesting a loan to purchase more seeds for her mushroom business. She would like to expand her business and eventually become a wholesaler and a big supplier to various people.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To buy more seeds

loans.name: Apiah

texts.en: Apiah, 28, is the mother of 2 children who has a food stall at her house where she sells vegetables, snacks, crispy chips, etc., and earns $11 a day. Her husband, R., sells steel door-to-door around the villages and earns $16 a week. She is requesting a loan of $75 to buy more goods for her stall, and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her stall

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
Francisco is a dairy farmer. He sells his cows' milk to the industrial plant PIL (Planta Industrializadora de Leche) Andina. His wife weaves shawls worn as part of the Bolivian cultural costumes known as cholitas. With these jobs the couple generates the income with which they support their 3 dependent children.

Francisco lives in the community of Huayrocondo, two hours from the city of La Paz.

The loan will be used to buy a cow of a medium sized breed in order to increase milk production. This is Francisco's second loan with Impro. His good payment record qualifies him for another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Francisco es productor de leche de vaca, la cual es comercializada a Pil Andina (Planta Industrializadora de Leche), la esposa realiza tejidos de mantas para cholitas y de esta manera consiguen los ingresos principales con los que cubren la manutención de sus 3 hijos que depende de él y de su esposa.

Vive en la Comunidad de Huayrocondo (A dos horas de la ciudad de La Paz).

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche. Es el segundo crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le faculta para otorgarle otro préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow of a high quality breed.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18, 12 and 7 years old. Fatuma owns a small food and charcoal store which she started in 2005. Everyday she works at her business from 6am to 10pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $450 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell for her business.

loans.name: Marifat

texts.ru:
Marifat A. lives in the town of Vahdat. She is 40 years old, married and has five children. She has secondary education. Marifat has a small grocery store at the market near her house. It is very convenient for the residents of the town. She brings in the merchandise from Dushanbe where she buys it wholesale. After she brings in the merchandise, she makes 20-30% profit on sales. This is not a very big income for her family. To increase her profits she needs to increase the commodity circulation and for this she plans to get a loan. By increasing the turnaround she will bring in new customers and satisfy the needs of the locals for reasonable prices. She has around 10 years experience in this field. Marifat plans to pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Азимова Марифат жительница города Вахдат.Ей 40 лет , замужем ,имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее . Марифат имеет небольшой продуктовый магазин на рынке рядом с домом. Это создает удобства для населения ее села.Привозит товар из города Душанбе, где покупает у оптовых продавцов. После того , как она привозит товар она продает его с прибылью в 20-30% .Это не очень большой доход для ее семьи.Для того , чтобы увеличить доход необходимо увеличить товарооборот.Для этого она планирует получить кредит. Увеличив товарооборот она привлечет новых клиентов и сможет удовлетворить потребности населения по доступным ценам. Опыт в данной сфере уже около 10 лет. Погасить кредит она сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase

loans.name: Quach Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Quach Thi D., 44 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) in 1999. Her husband died early, leaving her the sole bread-winner of the family. She has to take care of her two children who are still going to school. Her first loan of 100USD was used to breeding cows. After the first loan, she earned 50USD in profit. Up to now, she has borrowed 3000USD from TYM Fund in total. Each month she earns 150USD from poultry breeding. This time she wants to use the loan to pay for the living expenses and her children's school fees. Ms. D. wants to continue to be a member of TYM Fund. This time she proposes for a loan of 450 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Quách Thị Điền, 44 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1999. Chồng chị mất sớm một mình chị phải lam lũ nuôi 2 con ăn học. Số vốn vay 100USD lần đầu được chị đầu tư cho chăn nuôi bò. Sau khi kết thúc vòng vốn chị lãi được 50USD. Tính cho đến nay chị đã vay của Quỹ 3000USD. Mỗi tháng chị thu được 150USD tiền lãi bình quân từ chăn nuôi gà, vịt. Số tiền này được chị sử dụng cho sinh hoạt gia đình và các con ăn học. Chị luôn mong muốn được tham gia Quỹ lâu dài để vay vốn. Mức đề nghị của chị Điền vòng này là 450USD.

loans.use: Buy poultry

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Mrs. Horn C., 50, and her husband, Mr. Yorn Nhem, who live about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1981 and have six children, two sons and four daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Two sons are drivers and one daughter is a tailor.

Mrs. Horn and her husband have been selling fruits at Kor Ky market since 1980. They earn for living about $7.50 to $10 per day. Horn would like to repair her house but lacks money. So, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $1000 to repair her house.

loans.use: Horn would like to repair her house.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Fatuma S.. She is married and has three children aged between 4 and 15. In 2005, Fatuma established her café business. Fatuma requires a loan in order to purchase additional rice, beans, and cooking oil. In the future, Fatuma plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase additional rice, beans, and cooking oil

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam I. is married and has 4 children. She has received schooling through senior high. Mariam sells groceries like tinned fish, milk, Milo, tinned tomatoes, etc. in Abura, which she has done since 2006. Her husband is a steel bender.

Mariam uses her income to pay utility bills and her children's school fees. Mariam will use the loan to purchase more groceries such as milk, Milo, tinned fish, and other items. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mariam plans to pay their children's school fees and also to re-invest in her business.

loans.use: purchase more groceries like milk, Milo, tinned fish, and other items for re-sale

loans.name: Sairiniso

texts.en:
Sairiniso is 52 years old. She is a widow who raised her husband’s son (from his first marriage) alone. Thanks to her effort, he is now married with two children. 

Sairiniso has had a business baking Tajikistan's national sweets from granulated sugar for 16 years. Because her daughter-in-law is now helping her, she wants to expand her business. She doesn’t have enough capitol to meet customer demand. She is therefore asking for a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600) for the term of 12 months. 

With this loan, she is planning to purchase the necessary products to bake the national sweets. She will be able to earn more, improve her living, and ensure the best future for her grandchildren. With your help this will be possible. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dreams come reality.

loans.use: To purchase of the necessary products for baking the national sweets.

loans.name: Mwanaidi's Group

texts.en:
Mwanaidi has been selling alcohol in Dodoma, Tanzania, for 20 years. For the first time, she is taking out a loan so that she may increase her inventory. She is 44 years old, married, and has four children, ages 18, 13, 10 and 8. In addition, Mwanaidi cares for eight dependents.

Mwanaidi typically works for 12 hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $240 each month. Any additional profit she earns as a result of her loan she intends to invest back in her business so that it may continue to grow. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Mwamini, Halima and Tabu.

loans.use: To buy more alcohol to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Sambina

texts.en: Miss Sambina R. is a single woman living in Tangal, Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses. She lives with her father,mother, and two brothers. Her brothers are in grade 12 and 10.  Miss R. and her mother open their small hotel ten years ago. They sell different varieties of Nepali and Newari foods in their hotel. They especially love making Newari food because Newari food is very popular in that area. Due to lack of capital they cannot expand their business.  Miss R. requests a $200 loan to buy food materials for her business.

loans.use: To buy food materials

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Mr. Sor C., 37, and his wife, Mrs. Un Chhoy, 35, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1989 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of their children study in local school and the youngest son has not yet started his education.

Sor and his wife have been farming since they were young, growing vegetables and rice on their village land. Additionally, he is frequently hired by local villagers to carry rice and soil with his truck, thereby earning extra income. Sor is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a pesticide applicator for the farming business and a horse for resale.

loans.use: To purchase one pesticide applicator and a horse for resale.

loans.name: Rorng

texts.en:
Mrs. Rorng H. is a villager in Svay Meas village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. She cultivates vegetables on a 2-hectare field. In this plantation, she now faces a problem because she does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on the field. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Rorng H. decided to ask for a loan to hire them for this purpose.

Mrs. Rorng H. is 26 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of two years old. Her husband, Mr. Thoung Thuy, is a pig breeder. Her husband is also presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Roquelito

texts.en:
Roquelito is 30 years old and married to Jema Elena.  Being the head of the family, he must do his best to earn a living for his family.  He operates a passenger tricycle in their village at San M., Naguillan, Isabela while his wife stays at home and takes good care of their two children: Jerome – 4 years old and Jerus – 2 years old. 

Aside from operating a passenger tricycle, Roquelito sometimes works as a delivery boy of crackers in Isabela and Cagayan Province for additional income.  Since they have no other source of livelihood, Roquelito is asking for financial support amounting to $225 that he will use to purchase motorcycle equipment.  If there is extra money left, he is planning to use it as starting capital for a soap making business to be managed by his wife.  According to Roquelito, he learned the skills and knowledge in soap making through a training conducted by ASKI – the MFI providing the loan last year.  He thinks that it will be a good business so he wants to try it.  

He is hoping that if he started the soap making, they can maintain it and become stable for the future of their children.  Roquelito believes that a man of patience will someday become successful.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for his motorcycle and starting capital for a soapmaking business

loans.name: Kelly Silvana

texts.es:
La Sra. Kelly M. es hija de una cliente antigua de la institución, la Sra. Mery P.. Ambas se dedican a la comercialización de películas en Dvd, cds, mp3, etc. tienen el negocio desde hace cuatro años.
La madre le puso el negocio para ayudar a su hija económicamente, este es su primer crédito con Emprender y con el sistema microfinanciero, es una persona dedicada a su actividad ya que atiende de lunes a domingo, además de hacerce cargo de su pequeña hija, es madre soltera y trabaja arduamente para mantener a su pequeña hija.
El lugar del negocio es muy comercial y bien transitado por lo que existe demanda de la mercaderia que ella ofrece.
texts.en:
Kelly M. is the daugther of an old customer of the Emprender Microfinance institution, Mrs. Mery P.. For the past 4 years, both have worked selling DVDs, CDs, mp3s, etc. Mery started the business to help her daughter financially; this is Kelly's first loan with Emprender and in any microfinance institution. She is very devoted to her work as she tends to customers from Monday to Sunday while taking care of her small daughter. She is a single mother and she works hard to take care of her child. Her business is located in a heavily-trafficked, commercial area so there is plenty of demand for her goods.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her capital

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en:
Zahara owns a small food vendor store in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma. She belongs to Mji mwema "A" group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $155. Every day she works for 12 hours at her business.

She is requesting her first loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, to get more food for her family and to pay school fees for her children.

Zahara is married and has three children: ages 24, 20 and 17.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Valerio Felipe

texts.es: El Señor Valerio Felipe Hernández tiene 41 años de edad, su estado civil es soltero. Don Valerio tiene 2 hijos y todos sus hijos estudian. La actividad económica de Don Valerio es el destace de cerdo. Hace más de 8 años que se dedica a este negocio, anteriormente Valerio vendía cerdos a León, ya que antes vivía en malpaisillo y se dio cuenta de que lo mejor era el destace de cerdo y es así como decide quedarse con este negocio. Los propósitos de Don Valerio son de seguir con este negocio ya que es su principal fuente de ingresos para su familia. Es por eso que Don Valerio necesita este financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo y así invertir en compra de cerdos, yuca, maíz, papa y masa. El deseo de Don Valerio es de obtener más clientes y al mismo tiempo darle la calidad de sus productos. La cantidad que Valerio solicita es de C$6.000 córdobas.
texts.en:
Valerio Felipe Hernández is 41 years old and single. Valerio has two children, both of whom are in school. His economic activity is pork butchering, which he has done for eight years. Previously, he sold pigs in León while living in Malpaisillo. Then he realized that butchering was better and decided to stay in this business. His goal is to continue in this business, as it is the primary source of income for his family. Valerio needs this funding to invest in the purchase of pigs, yucca, corn, potatoes and dough. He wishes to obtain more customers while at the same time giving them quality products. The amount he is requesting is 6,000 córdobas.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana is a native of Baliangao. She is 65 years old now. Her husband works as a government driver in their town. They have been blessed with four chidren. Marciana has a fishing business that she is hoping will eventually grow and develop so that they can save more for their retirement phase.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 14,900 for the purchase of parts to repair her motor boat. She said that if they have a good catch, they can easily pay their investment from it. She is so thankful to Paglaum because of the trust they have given her.

loans.use: To purchase motor boat parts for repairs.

loans.name: Norman De Jesús

texts.es:
En el municipio de Nagarote de la ciudad de León, el señor Norman S. se dedica a laborar arduamente en su negocio de venta de lácteos el cual son elaborados de la materia prima como lo es la leche de donde obtiene el queso, la cuajada y la crema.

El negocio le ha sido de mucho beneficio porque ha logrado salir adelante junto con su familia. Hoy en día espera en que Ceprodel le proporcione un crédito para la compra de leche , cuajo y sal para así elaborar los productos lácteos y ofertarlos en su localidad y también ofertar la leche pura la cual es comercializada de igual manera que el queso, la cuajada y la crema.
texts.en:
In the area of Nagarote in the city of León, señor Norman Solis works hard in the dairy business. He uses milk to make cheese, cuajada (a typical Nicaraguan cheese), and cream. His business has benefitted him a lot because he has managed to get ahead with his family. Today he hopes that Ceprodel will offer him a credit to purchase milk, rennet, and salt to make his products and sell them in his area. He will also sell milk, which he sells just like the cheese, cuajada, and cream.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase milk, rennet, and salt

loans.name: Shohida

texts.ru: Шохида успешно проводит свою предпринимательскую деятельность. Раньше она торговала на непостоянном месте, а сейчас арендовала торговую точку на местном рынке. Капитал ее бизнеса возрос, и ассортимент увеличился в несколько раз. Сейчас она кроме детской одежды включила несколько видов мужской одежды. Это позволяет ей увеличить реализацию, а естественно и прибыль. Ее дети ходят в школу, а муж находится на заработках в России. Шохида просит займ для того, чтобы увеличить ассортимент детской одежды.
texts.en:
Shohida successfully runs her own business. In the past, she did not have a permanent sales location, but now she rents a trade outlet at the local market. Her working capital has grown, and the variety of goods she carries has increased several times over. In addition to children's clothing, she now includes several types of men's clothing. This has allowed her to increase her sales and, naturally, her profits. Her children attend school, and her husband is away working in Russia. Shohida is asking for a loan in order to expand the selection of children's clothing she carries.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory expansion

loans.name: Cresilda

texts.en:
Cresilda D. is from the village of Cagay-anon, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Cresilda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cresilda owns & operates a business selling seafood such as shrimp and fish in the local community. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood to the local community. Cresilda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Cresilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cresilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Cresilda is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to repair their residential house. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Cresilda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair their residential house

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys K. is fifty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Gladys is a trader and works to support her husband so as to be able to provide for the family. She trades in smoked fish. She sells on a table in the market square of her community and treks to other towns to sell on their market days as well.

Gladys has been in business for over thirty years and wants a loan to buy smoked fish in bulk. She aspires to sponsor all her children in school to the higher levels.

loans.use: To buy more smoked fish to sell

loans.name: Celia Victoria

texts.es:
La señora  Celia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Totoritas”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Chimu, el distrito de Puno, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 32 años de edad, estado civil casada, y es madre de 1 hijo.  Tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en La Comunidad de Chimu Sector Progreso.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace casi 7 años,  su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para la fabricación de quesanas (tejas, calaminas). 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 2000.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de material quesana y chillihua, con ello Celia va a elaborar sus artesanías en totora, también quesanas, las cuales lleva a diferentes ferias de la región.

Su deseo es poner una tienda de repuestos para carros  en Puno.
A ella le gustan los ahorros y la puntualidad.
texts.en:
Celia belongs to the “Las Totoritas” Community Bank, which is located in the Chimu community in the Puno district, in the Puno province, in the department of Puno. She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of 1 son. She has completed high school and she lives in the Chimu Sector Progreso community.

She has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for almost 7 years. Her first loan was for 300.00 PEN, which she used to make “quesanas” (a type of rush mat).

Now she requires a loan of 2000.00 PEN for the purchase of quesana and chillihua material. With these, Celia will make her reed handicrafts and quesanas, which she brings to different markets in the region.

Her wish to set up an auto parts shop in Puno. She likes the savings and the punctuality.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of chillihua and reed (material to make handicrafts)

loans.name: Doris Luz

texts.es:
Doris es una madre soltera de 47 años de edad que vive en el caserío La Zaranda, ubicado en el distrito de Pítipo, a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella vive con su hijo de 8 años de edad y posee un pequeño negocio de librería en su domicilio, donde vende artículos escolares, este negocio es la única fuente de ingreso económico de su hogar y es de mucha ayuda a su comunidad debido a que se encuentra ubicado frente al único colegio de su caserío.

Doris está solicitando un crédito de 2500 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la compra de útiles escolares y libros requeridos por los estudiantes de la zona y así seguir apoyando a las familias de su comunidad.

Ella ha manejado este negocio por más de tres años y es considerada como una excelente cliente de nuestra institución debido a que se le ha atendido con tres créditos, los cuales los ha cancelado puntualmente. 

Su más grande anhelo es hacer crecer su negocio poniendo mas librerías en los caseríos aledaños y así reunir los recursos suficientes que posibiliten una educación de calidad para su hijo.
texts.en:
Doris is a 47 year-old single mother who lives in the town of La Zaranda, located in the district of Pítipo, one hour from the city of Chiclayo. Doris lives with her 8 year-old son and she has a small bookstore in her house, where she sells school supplies. This business is the only source of income for her household and it is also very helpful to her community because it is located in front of the only school in the town. Doris is requesting a loan of 2,500 PEN that she plans to use to buy school supplies and books needed by the students in the neighborhood and thereby continue helping the families of her community. She has had this business for more than three years and is considered an excellent client in our institution because she has had three loans and she repaid them punctually. Her greatest dream is to grow her business by opening more bookstores in nearby towns. That way she could have enough income to make it possible for her son to have a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school supplies and books

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas K. H., age 32, is married and has two children. She lives with her husband and her children in Phnom Penh City. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling Chinese noodles and fried rice at her house, earning approximately US$10 per day. This amount is the primary source of income of the family. Her husband works for a private company as an accountant, earning an income of US$8 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for businesses in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, H. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, H. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more food and supplements for her food shop. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy more food and supplements for her restaurant

loans.name: April Joy

texts.en:
April Joy is 20 years old and already married to Jayson who is a farmer in their village.  They are living a simple life in Annayatan, Enrile, Cagayan. The is an agricultural community where farming is the main source of income of most residents. April is an electronic load retailer in their village.  She sells cell phone loads.  In this way, she was able to assist her husband in providing their basic needs.  

At present, she would like to borrow a loan of PHP5, 000 from the KIVa lenders that she can use as additional capital for her reloading business.  She wanted to strengthen the business in order to increase her income and be progressive.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Karen Liseth

texts.es: Karen Liseth T. de 29 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Delgado municipio del departamento de San Salvador, vive con sus tres hijos todos menores de edad y su  esposo quien se dedica a trabajar como mecánico. Karen posee su propio negocio ubicado en el centro de Ciudad Delgado, donde vende variedad de verduras, el crédito que solicita Karen es para surtir su puesto con más variedad de productos para incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Karen Liseth T. is 29 years old and lives in Ciudad Delgado, a municipality in the department of San Salvador. She lives with her three children, all of whom are young, and her husband, who works as a mechanic. Karen has her own business located in the center of Ciudad Delgado, where she sells a variety of vegetables. The loan that she is requesting will be used to supply her stand with a larger variety of products to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her business with vegetables

loans.name: Virgen De Urkupiña Group

texts.es: El grupo “Virgen D. Urkupiña” esta representado por el señor Nicolás y conformado por 16 miembros  los cuales son personas responsables y muy trabajadoras. La mayoría D. los miembros del grupo se dedican al comercio D. diferentes productos como  Abarrotes en tiendas D. barrió, comida rápida en sus puerta D. sus domicilios, perfumes, material escolar, combustibles y a actividades como el transporte publico, construcción D. viviendas, cuidado D. viñedos y el servicio D. peluquería y barbería. En cuanto a la competencia el entorno donD. se desarrollan las actividades cuenta con la demanda D. los consumidores por lo que aun no se ven afectados por la competencia, pero los socios desean incrementar sus ingresos para poder otorgar a sus hogares una mejor calidad D. vida incrementando su mercadería, insumos y adquiriendo herramientas D. trabajo que ayuden a generar mayores beneficio. El banco se conformo con socias que ya cuentan con experiencia D. trabajo en créditos grupales y cuentan con buenas referencias crediticias para acceder al crédito.

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter O. is 32 years old, married to Mary Achieng, and has 4 school-age children. He has worked as a partner in a garage in Naivasha town for the last 9 years. Peter was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan to buy a new spraying machine for painting cars. He wants to expand his garage and turn it into a big-name garage in town.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their families across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a new spraying machine to paint cars.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her shop's inventory

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma S. is 62 years old, married to Felimon L. S., and currently living at Prinza, Teresa Rizal. She is engaged in a hog-fattening business (raising of pigs) with the support of her loving husband. 

She has six children, the eldest being 41 years old and the youngest 24. Five of her children have graduated as degree holders through loans from the Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI). 

Norma S. will use the loan for raising more pigs, and for the expansion of her future hog-farming business, in order to support her family in a stable life. She hopes to see herself enjoying the profits of her business and to have a good life. 

She is also enjoying the benefit of having loans from ASHI because she can gradually achieve her goals in life. During almost three years with ASHI Norma S. has shown herself to be industrious, and to have determination and discipline. She gives all of her time for her family and business for the fulfillment of family dreams. They would love to have their own car someday.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to grow her business

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
A. Byambasuren is 44 years old and lives with his family in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. They live together in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. He and his wife have six children, ages 4 to 22, the oldest of whom is in college. His wife operates a mobile food service and leather painting business.

Bayambasuren operates a jewelry-making business in his town. He makes a variety of gold and silver jewelry for his many customers. Bayambasuren started his business in 1998 in a small rented workspace. He has built up a stable operation over the years and has become a skilled jewelry crafter. His business is very important to him and he says, “ I am working hard because I have many mouths to feed.”

Byambasuren hopes to continue his success in the future and hopes to save enough to one day own his own workplace. He is requesting an 850,000 tugrug (~598 USD) loan to purchase jewelry decorating materials for his business.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: to purchase jewelry decorating materials

loans.name: Pioneta

texts.en:
Pioneta Garsenilla has experienced tremendous failure on her farm before. She thought that she would not able to recover, but CEVI helped her and gave her capital to start again and to sustain her business. The income she makes  from farming has helped her to buy food, clothing and other basic needs. 

She would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies so she can increase her harvest. When her income rises, she will be able to provide for her family and better supply of all their needs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase equipment such as plates, tables and chairs for the business.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata SADIO est une femme de 44 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfant. Elle est membre du banc villageois de KADIOR depuis 7 ans et demis et a une bonne expérience de crédit pour y avoir accédé à 15 fois de suite. Elle fait un petit commerce d'huile de palme, une activité qui lui permet de se procurer des ressources financière et de participer au bien être familiale.
texts.en:
Aminata SADIO is a 44 year-old woman. She is married and a mother of two. She has been a member of the Kadior "Banc Villageois" (village loan group) for seven and a half years, and has significant experience with credit as she has obtained loans fifteen times in a row. She has a small business trading palm oil, an activity which allow her to access financial resources and to contribute to her family well-being.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her invested capital

loans.name: Pastor

texts.en:
Pastor P., 54, manages the family farm. He works to make sure that his family has enough for their daily needs and to improve their standard of living. Married to Rodilyn P., they are blessed with three children. 

Pastor has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. He uses the money he borrows to expand and improve the farm.

Now with your help, he would like to apply for a Php 13,000 loan which will be used as a source of added capital to buy equipment and raw materials needed for the farm to continue to grow and fulfill Pastor's dream of a good and comfortable life with his family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying equipment and raw materials needed for the farm to continue its production.

loans.name: Estelita's Group

texts.en:
Estelita C. is from the village of San Andres. She is 47 years old. Estelita is the leader of a 7-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Estelita C. Group.

Estelita is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Estelita owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Estelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Estelita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase new items to her expand product offering. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Estelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Papa

texts.en:
Papa D. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets at the market and is requesting a loan to stock pairs of trousers and dresses, etc. to sell. Papa is 29 years old and is married to with a husband who is a nurse. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock pairs of trousers and dresses etc. to sell.

loans.name: Baasanhuu

texts.en:
Baasanhuu is 50 years-old and lives with her husband and son in Zavhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a “ger” in a yard which belongs to her brother. They have been living together in their current home for two years. Currently, Baasanhuu operates a door-to-door meal trading business in her town. She makes the meals at her home and delivers them to her customers.

Baasanhuu started her business in 2009 and has steadily expanded her business and gained experience. Originally, she had a small restaurant at a local vocational trading center between 2005-2009. Her business is well known amongst her customers and she has been planning to create her own workplace in the future. Baasanhuu is a very hardworking person who has good communication skills. She says, “I am working hard to be financially supportive for my son's life.”  She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~ 225 USD) loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase scaffolding & merchandise for her store

loans.name: Foluke

texts.en: Foluke A. A. is a widow with 4 children. Life as a widow has been so challenging to her and she hopes to overcome the challenge. She is 50 years old.  She sells planks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for long. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She say thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine is married to a market vendor and they have four children who go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.   Previously was operating a ladies salon but changed her business enterprise to food vending. Currently Justine owns a banana stall in Kalerwe market, selling bananas. She has been doing this for three months.  She buys bananas from the very market where she works and she works seven days a week.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  Justine sells to all categories of people at wholesale and retail. Justine aspires to build her own house. Her business challenges include thieves and seasonality.  She decides to work with MCDT because she wanted to get timely loans. She has been with MCDT for over five years.  Justine resides in and rents a one-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of  bananas

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es:
La señora Roxana vive en casa propia en la zona de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo y sus dos hijos.
La señora Roxana es costurera de  una empresa textil y su esposo es chofer de transporte público, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de una cocina e instalación de gas domiciliario, esto mejorará las condiciones de vida de su familia.
Esta es la décima ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Roxana lives in her own house in the Pasankeri area in the western part of the city of La Paz with her husband and two children. Roxana is employed as a seamstress in a textile firm and her husband is a public transportation driver; their combined income supports the family. She will use the requested funds to build a kitchen and have domestic usage gas installed which will improve her family’s living conditions. This is the 10th loan request and the socioeconomic evaluation conducted yielded a positive rating thereby qualifying her for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a kitchen and pay for gas installation.

loans.name: Lizeth Katherine

texts.es:
Lizeth es una madre de familia de 27 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus dos hijos en una zona urbano – marginal del distrito de Castilla de la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre, ubicada a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace tres años a la venta de prendas de vestir y artículos para el hogar en un pequeño establecimiento instalado en la vivienda donde reside. Sus principales clientes son las personas que viven por la zona, ella empezó vendiendo ropa por pedidos y poco a poco ha ido ampliando su negocio. Este negocio es una fuente importante de ingresos para su familia por lo que trata de sacarlo adelante de la menor manera posible.

Lizeth desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo mas mercadería para así poder ampliar sus ventas y percibir mayores ganancias. Por este motivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 700 nuevos soles que le ayuden a realizar su objetivo.

Lizeth es una mujer que da lo mejor de si para ver a su familia progresar, su mayor anhelo es llegar a tener una casa propia donde puedan radicar de una manera estable ya que actualmente viven en la vivienda de un familiar. En la zona sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una mujer tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
Lizeth is 27 and is the mother of a family. She lives together with her husband and her 2 children in an urban zone, marginal to the Castilla district in Piura, in the region of the same name, located 3 hours from the city of Chiclayo. For 3 years she has worked selling clothing zips and household articles in a small establishment located in the home where she lives. Her principle clients are the people that live in her zone. Lizeth began selling clothes by orders and little by little she has expanded her business. This business is an important source of income for her family, who she tries to move forward in the best way possible. Lizeth wants to expand her business by acquiring more merchandise to increase her sales and in turn receive better earnings. This is her motive for seeking a loan of 700 nuevos soles from Edpyme for the first time, as the loan will help her realise her objectives. Lizeth is a woman who likes nothing more than to see her family progress. Her biggest goal is to arrive at having her own home where she can live in a stable situation, as she and her family actually live in a relative's house at the moment. Amongst her neighbours and acquaintances in the zone she is known as a very calm and responsible woman.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen has been a resident of the city called Chichawatni in Pakistan for the past 14 years. Her husband has a scrap business in the local market. 
Forty four years old, Nasreen has eight children. Only three of them are getting their education while the other two do labor work to financially support their family. 

Nasreen sells bangles to help her husband financially. She is applying for a loan from Asasah for her husband who is a loader by trade. He has been in this work for the past ten years. He uses his donkey cart to load different items, such as fruits & vegetables, and delivers it to the designated places. Presently, his cart has become rough and needs replacement. Nasreen is hopeful that, with his new donkey cart, her husband will be able to work more efficiently and provide better services to his clients.

loans.use: Purchase a new donkey cart for loading business.

loans.name: Urantuya

texts.en: Urantuya D. is 43-year-old widow who lives in Hovd province, western Mongolia with her two children in their own house. Urantuya is a dentist who operates a dental clinic in her town. She serves local people with all types of dentistry as well as making artificial teeth. One artificial tooth costs from 15,000 to 18,000 MNT on average. As an experienced and skilled dentist, she has established a wide customer base and her services are well known among the local citizens. Urantuya is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to expand her dental clinic.

loans.use: To expand her dental business

loans.name: Koulossama Ii Group

texts.fr:
KOULOSSAMA II  est un groupe constitué de  neuf femmes mariées du village de  Nènèsso,  dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana, du cercle de SAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide et du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a trois ans.  
SEGUETIO C., la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture,  au grand marché de Kimparana. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25.000 à 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Koulossama II is a group made up of nine married women from the village of Nènèsso in the arrondissement of Kimparana, circle of San, region of Ségou (Mali's fourth administrative region). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 35 years old and have five children. They are peanut and corn farmers. Three years ago, planning to put their farming on a sounder economic footing, they joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. Seguetio C., the group's president, plans on using her loan to buy peanut seed, small tools and fertilizer in the big marketplace of Kimparana. After the rains, the harvest will be stored until prices rise enough for it to be sold in the big marketplace in Kimparana and nearby markets at retail (but often wholesaled) to buyers mostly from bigger cities. The group's members hope to realize a profit of from 25,000 to 35,000 FCFA each to pay back their loans and topay for day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, small toolsand fertilizer

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel M.
Samvel M. is a long term resident of the Kaps village located in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He has been engaged in cattle breeding and growing vegetables for over twenty years.  He is happily married with three children; a 7-year-old daughter, a 14-year-old daughter, and an 8-year-old son.  He supports his brother in Gyumri with vegetables and meat from his farm.  He would like a loan to purchase additional cattle and fertilizers.  By growing his business he is expecting the family income to increase by 20%.  The additional funds will be used for home and farm renovations and supporting the education of his children.  Samvel particularly enjoys living on a farm and the beautiful environment of the Kaps area.  Most people of Kaps are engaged in agricultural production and Samvel has many close relatives nearby.

loans.use: cattle and fertilizers

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
Batchuluun is a 50-year-old man who lives with his wife and five children in Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). His two eldest daughters are married but live in their parent’s house. The next daughter, Batchimeg, is a 20-year-old college student. Batchuluun’s eldest son, Amartuvshin, 18 years old, is a design upholsterer in an auto maintenance garage. His youngest son, Amarbayasgalan, 15 years old, attends a local secondary school. Batchuluun’s wife works in a carwash center as a washer. 

Batchuluun started his taxi business in 2007. He is one of Credit Mongol's reliable VIP customers. He has taken out a micro-loan twice and used it for building a house for his family. He is a very hardworking family-oriented man. This time he wants to fit the house with a local heating system before the winter. Therefore he needs to buy a special stove, boiler, pipes and some insulation materials. He has already done all the necessary calculations and found a person who installs heating systems. The loan Batchuluun is requesting will be used to buy materials for the heating system and insulation materials for the house.

loans.use: to buy materials for a heating system and insulation materials for the house

loans.name: Jose Armando

texts.es: El señor José Armando M. N. vive con sus abuelos ya que se encuentra separado de su conyuge hace tres años aproximadamente, tiene dos hijos a los cuales envía una pensión por mutuo acuerdo. El cliente desempeña labor de chofer de mototaxi solo por medio tiempo por que trabaja adicionamente como vigilante de la Municipalidad de Ica también realiza trabajos de informática en su domicilio de manera temporal. Solicita el crédito para sus gastos personales y tener mejor calidad de vida, se otorgará el crédito por contar con capacidad para asumir una nueva obligación.
texts.en:
Mr. José Armando M. N. lives with his grandparents because he’s been separated from his spouse for about three years now. He has two children for whom he sends a monthly, mutually agreed upon, child support stipend. He works as a mototaxi (motorcycle equipped with an attached cabin to transport passengers and cargo) driver part time because he also is employed as a municipal watchman by the city of Ica and he also does occasional computer work at home. He is asking for the loan for personal expenses and to have a better quality of life. The loan will be granted because he has the capacity to take on a new obligation.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For personal expenses.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou R. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fish vending and pig fattening. Her husband, Misael R., who is 37 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have three children who are 6 to 14 years old. Marilou joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marilou has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase more fish to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her family. Marilou R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  Photo was taken at the center because her business was sold out early in the morning. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Katherine Lizeth

texts.es:
Catherine Lizete M. Suárez tiene 19 años.  Es soltera vive sola en el cantón de Ventanas en la provincia de los Ríos en la ciudadela Nueva Esperanza, no tiene cargas familiares. 

Catherine es un socio de la ventanilla rural Nuevo Porvenir, se encuentra  en la ciudadela Nueva Esperanza perteneciente al cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla integran 10 socios,   en su gran mayoría se dedican a las actividades de comercio. 

Catherine estudia y se dedica a vender ropa como ambulante. Realiza sus compras cada dos meses en la ciudad de Guayaquil o Perú, y las ventas lo realiza en el cantón Ventanas.

Solicita el préstamo para surtir más su mercadería. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Su sueño es hacer una casa y terminar sus estudios. Dice no tener al momento desafíos que enfrente la familia ni el negocio.
Le gusta en sus tiempos libres escuchar música.
texts.en:
Katherine Lizete M. S. is 19 years old. She is single and she lives alone in the community of Ventanas, in the province of Los Rios, Nueva Esperanza. She does not have a family of her own. 

Katherine is a member of the community bank named Nuevo Porvenir. It is located in the village of Nueva Esperanza in Ventanas. It is a community bank with 10 members, and the great majority of the members are merchants. 

Katherine is going to school and she sells clothing door to door. She makes her purchases every two months in the city of Guayaquil or in Peru. She carries out her sales in Ventanas.

She requests a loan to add merchandise to her business. She sees this loan as an opportunity for success. Her dream is to have a house built for her and to finish her studies. She says she doesn’t have specific challengers pertaining to family or her business. 

She enjoys listening to music in her spare time.

loans.use: To add variety to her clothing business.

loans.name: Sonia Gladys

texts.es:
Sonia es socia del Banco Comunal “Azangarinas Valientes” ubicado en el distrito Azángaro,  provincia de Azángaro, departamento de Puno, tiene 34 años de edad, de estado civil  conviviente y con 02 hijos, realizó estudios de educación superior.

La señora viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 04 años, con un préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, dinero que utilizó para incrementar el capital de  su negocio de venta de papa y carne.

Ahora solicitará un nuevo préstamo de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, dinero que le servirá para comprar papas.

Su sueño es tener un carro y una tienda de abarrotes en Juliaca.

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la facilidad del préstamo y la responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Sonia is a member of the Azangarinas Valientes community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Puno.  She is 34 years old, partnered and has 2 children.  She studied at a college level.

Sonia got her first Movimiento Manuela Ramos loan 4 years ago.  She used the loan, for S/.500 new soles, to buy potatoes and meat for her grocery business.  She is now applying for a S/.1,000 new soles loan to buy more potatoes for the business.

Sonia's dream is to own a car and a store in Juliaca.  She likes her community bank because it provides a relatively easy and responsible way for her to borrow money.

loans.use: Buy products for grocery business.

loans.name: Akwata Empola Gambwa Women's Group A-Mityana

texts.en: Retailing has been 30-year-old N. Lukia's business occupation for the last 10 years in Gambwa-Mityana. At her premise, she predominately sells rice, beans, maize flour, etc. Before the inception of this business, she had a penchant for farming. She has not dispensed with her farming enterprise notwithstanding. She still finds time to go and tend to her crops and gardens, though much time is spent at her retail shop. This hardworking mother of 4 says weekly her profits are 100,000 shillings. With this loan she is looking at buying more retail items such as sugar, bread, maize flour, etc. for reselling. Lukia belongs to Akwata Empola Gambwa Group-Mityana.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail items such as sugar, maize flour, bread, etc., for reselling

loans.name: Ismayil

texts.en:
Ismayil M. is a 34-year-old man living in Nurulu village, Imishli region. He is married and has two sons. Ismayil has been engaged in the cattle-breeding business for the last two years. He now has two cows and with the help of this 1000 AZN loan he purchased three more cows. Ismayil sells meat and dairy he produces at the Imishli central bazaar.  His wife helps him in his business. 

This is the first loan Ismayil has received from Aqroinvest and KIVA. After repaying this loan he plans to take out another loan to open a farm.

loans.use: to buy three cows

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To build two new rooms in their house.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is from the village of Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 65 years old. Nenita is married and has three children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business in agricultural sector in raising crops. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Nenita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Math

texts.en: Math K. is 30 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish and dried fish in the busy local market for more than two years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or buys them from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She is married to Lors Yor, 47, who fishes in and around the lakes of his community. They are blessed with four kids, and all of them are single, still studying in school. This family could earn a daily income of approximately US$10 per day to ensure that the family has a comfortable living standard. Recently, the family is facing difficulty with their living conditions due to their house needing repair. To solve the problem, Math K. would like a loan to repair a part of her broken house.

loans.use: To repair a part of her broken house.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
